item.title: 11 Exercise: /Orders/
item.description:
In this exercise you should finish the Store API by enabling it to handle orders.

You should now have 2 collections in your store database:

  • users
  • products

And you should be able to view an API in the browser and get, post, put and delete through this api.

On this
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
In this exercise you should finish the Store API by enabling it to handle orders.

You should now have 2 collections in your store database:

  • users
  • products

And you should be able to view an API in the browser and get, post, put and delete through this api.

On this url you can se an example of how an order should be structured.

An order has information about one or more products in an order. It has information about the user who placed the order, and it has information about the status of the order.

Your job is to create 5 routes for the orders. A get, a get one, a post, a put, and a delete route.

item.title: 08 Exercise: twitter & socket.io
item.description: Based on what we have done today and what you know from the earlier classes create an app that gets the latest tweet containing words of your own choice, and pushes it to a webpage made with the use of the express.js framework.
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded: Based on what we have done today and what you know from the earlier classes create an app that gets the latest tweet containing words of your own choice, and pushes it to a webpage made with the use of the express.js framework.

item.title: 05 Exercise: learnyounode
item.description:
Learnyounode is an intro to Node.js via a set of self-guided workshops.

It is run through the console and everything is explained along the way.
This workshop covers what you have seen in the Lynda.com tutorials for this class, and you will have to use the node documentation
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
Learnyounode is an intro to Node.js via a set of self-guided workshops.

It is run through the console and everything is explained along the way.
This workshop covers what you have seen in the Lynda.com tutorials for this class, and you will have to use the node documentation to be able to complete the workshops.

Install
In order to install the workshop you should open your console an write:

npm install learnyounode -g

If you get an error try to prepend the command with "sudo" 

sudo npm install learnyounode -g

and type in your password for your computer.

Run
Run the workshop with this command 

learnyounode

Have fun! and see you next friday.

item.title: 09.1 Exercise: MongoDB Getting Started
item.description:
The information you will need for this exercise can be found at this website.

Create a database called store. In this there should be a collection called users, and a collection called products.

Insert
Insert 3 users in the users collection. The 2 below, and one your create yourself (your
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
The information you will need for this exercise can be found at this website.

Create a database called store. In this there should be a collection called users, and a collection called products.

Insert
Insert 3 users in the users collection. The 2 below, and one your create yourself (your own name e.g). You can insert these one at a time or all 3 at the same time by wrapping them in an array [ ]

{
        "name" : "Claus",
        "lastName" : "Bové",
        "address" : "Svanemøllevej 56",
        "phone" : "004512345678",
        "email" : "clbo@kea.dk"
}

{
        "name" : "Anna",
        "lastName" : "Messner",
        "address" : "Lygten 16",
        "phone" : "004512345678",
        "email" : "anna@stud.kea.dk"
}


Insert 3 products in the products collection. The 2 below, and one your create yourself. You can insert these one at a time or all 3 at the same time by wrapping them in an array [ ]

{
        "make" : "Burton Menswear London",
        "name" : "Print T-shirt",
        "color" : "white",
        "price" : 16,
        "size" : ["small", "medium", "large", "x-large"],
        "details" : {
                "length" : "standard",
                "fit" : "normal",
                "fabric" : "jersey",
                "Neckline" : "Crew neck",
                "Total length" : "28.0\"  (Size M)"
        }
}

{
        "make" : "ONLY",
        "name" : "ONLNEW - Slim fit jeans",
        "color" : "black olive",
        "price" : 30,
        "size" : ["x-small", "small", "medium", "large", "x-large"],
        "details" : {
                "length" : "long",
                "fit" : "normal",
                "Pockets" : "Back pocket",
                "outer leg length" : "40.0\" (Size S)",
                "inner leg length" :  "31.5\" (Size S)"
        }
}

`

Querying
Select all users, and after that select all products.
Then select the user with your own name, and then a single product of your own choice, by querying on the “_id”

Update
The user with the name “Claus” should have another address.
Change the address to “Lygten 16”

The product ONLY, needs to have the name field changed to “ONLY NEW - Slim fit jeans”

Remove
Remove the user with the name Anna
Remove the product with the make “Burton Menswear London”

item.title: 09.2 Exercise: MongoDB 2.0.0 Driver
item.description:
In the following exercises you should create 4 different applications (4 different javascript files), each containing 1 of the 4 CRUD operations.

You can read about the MongoDB 2.0.0 driver CRUD operations here

Find()
Create an app that reads all users from your “store” database and prints them
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
In the following exercises you should create 4 different applications (4 different javascript files), each containing 1 of the 4 CRUD operations.

You can read about the MongoDB 2.0.0 driver CRUD operations here

Find()
Create an app that reads all users from your “store” database and prints them out in the console.

Insert()
Insert a user into the database. The user's id should be an automatic generated id.

Update()
Update the inner object “details” in the "products" collection so that the length becomes "long" of the "Burton Menswear London" product.

Remove()
Remove one of your users from the store database.

FindOne()
Get the user you inserted earlier in this exercise. You should identify the person from it´s id, and for that you have to use the ObjectID method.

item.title: 09.3 Exercise: MongoDB native driver and Express
item.description:
Create an application that makes use of Express.js, MongoDB and the mongodb native driver.

The goal is, from the browser, to be able to request: localhost:3000/users and get a response with the data from the database in JSON format.
The result above is diffent from what you
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
Create an application that makes use of Express.js, MongoDB and the mongodb native driver.

The goal is, from the browser, to be able to request: localhost:3000/users and get a response with the data from the database in JSON format.
The result above is diffent from what you will get out of the user request

To get the nicely formated view, you can install the extension "JSONView" (for Google Chrome, or something similar for the other browsers).

Solution can be found on github

item.title: Curriculum
item.description:
Curriculum
The following resources is the course curriculum.
Your exam project should demonstrate the use of topics from this curriculum and you will furthermore be asked questions from this curriculum at the oral exam.

* Note that this is not a complete list yet, it will grow as we advance through
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
Curriculum
The following resources is the course curriculum.
Your exam project should demonstrate the use of topics from this curriculum and you will furthermore be asked questions from this curriculum at the oral exam.

* Note that this is not a complete list yet, it will grow as we advance through the elective.

Command Line Client

  • The Command Line Crash Course
    • Paths, Folders, Directories (pwd)
    • Make A Directory (mkdir)
    • Change Directory (cd)
    • List Directory (ls)
    • Remove Directory (rmdir)
    • Making Empty Files (Touch, New-Item)
    • Removing A File (rm)

Node.js

  • Node.js Playlist
  • Node.js v4.2.4 Documentation
    • About this Documentation
    • Synopsis
    • Buffer
    • File System
    • Global Objects
    • Modules
    • Path
    • Readline
    • Stream
    • Timers
    • URL
    • util
    • Events

Express.js

  • Building a Website with Node.js and Express.js
  • Writing middleware for use in Express apps
  • Using middleware
  • 4.x API

Websockets

  • Websockets Playlist

REST API

  • RESTful Service Best Practices
  • JSON

MongoDB

  • https://docs.mongodb.org/manual/introduction/

Mongo Crud Tutorials

  • https://docs.mongodb.org/manual/tutorial/insert-documents/
  • https://docs.mongodb.org/manual/tutorial/query-documents/
  • https://docs.mongodb.org/manual/tutorial/modify-documents/
  • https://docs.mongodb.org/manual/tutorial/remove-documents/
  • Data Modeling Introduction
  • http://expressjs.com/en/guide/database-integration.html#mongo

item.title: Day 1 - Introduction
item.description:
Time: 5/2-2016, 08:30 - 13:20

In this first class you will get introduced to what we are going to work on the next 14 weeks.

You will also get an introduction to the Node.js server, you will download and install the server, and you will create
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
Time: 5/2-2016, 08:30 - 13:20

In this first class you will get introduced to what we are going to work on the next 14 weeks.

You will also get an introduction to the Node.js server, you will download and install the server, and you will create your first webserver and webpage. This webserver will run locally on your computer and it will be accessable on your local network for everybody.

Objectives:

  • An overview of what will be covered in the next 14 weeks.
    • Curriculum
    • Exam and Mandatory Assignments
  • Introduction to and installation of Node.js.
  • Make your first Webserver and a Hello World web page.

Tools:

  • Git
  • Sublime Text 3
  • Node.js

Exercises:

  • Install git
  • The Command Line Crash Course
  • Introduction to the Mac OS X Command Li
  • Unix/Linux Command Reference
  • My first Webserver (used as "follow along" example in this class)

Code on Github: 

  • keanodejs
  • Todays examples

item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
Time: 11/3-2016, 08:30 - 13:20

Prequisite
Before the start of this day 6 class, you should have completed the online Lynda.com tutorial on

  • Building a Website with Node.js and Express.js (2h 46m)

If you have not created a free account yet you can do it by following these steps.

ExpressJS is maybe the most used Module on the Node.js platform, and today we will work with that.

Curriculum

  • Building a Website with Node.js and Express.js (2h 46m)
  • Express.js 4.x API
  • Expressjs Getting Started
    • http://expressjs.com/en/starter/installing.html
    • http://expressjs.com/en/starter/hello-world.html
    • http://expressjs.com/en/starter/basic-routing.html
  • Writing middleware for use in Express apps
  • Using middleware

Supplements to the Curriculum

Exercises

Code on Github:

Materials from today
